title: 104_hr1114
content: 16- and 17-year-olds are authorized to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors. Employees who are 16 and 17 years old are allowed to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards, but they are not permitted to operate or unload them. Employees aged 16 and 17 can load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards. They are not allowed to operate or unload them. The equipment must have an on-off switch with a key-lock or similar system controlled by employees aged 18 or older. The switch must be kept in the off position when not in use, and employers must provide notice that the equipment meets safety standards for minors. The Secretary will publish safety standards for scrap paper balers and paper box compactors certified by the American National Standards Institute. Employers must report any injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 involving these machines. Employees must report any injuries or fatalities of individuals under 18 resulting from contact with scrap paper balers or paper box compactors. The reports will include details such as employer and employee information, incident date, injury description, and equipment manufacturer details. These reports will be used by the Secretary to assess the impact of safety standards on child safety. Employees must report injuries or fatalities of individuals under 18 from incidents involving scrap paper balers or paper box compactors to the Secretary within 10 days. The reports should include details like the date of the incident, injury description, and equipment manufacturer information. The Secretary cannot solely rely on these reports to determine violations of child labor laws and must conduct investigations before making any determinations. These reporting requirements will expire 2 years after enactment. SEC. 2. Civil money penalty amended for Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Section 16(e) is updated to include penalties for violations of section 12 or section 13(c)(5). SEC. 3. Construction clarification for apprentices and student learners exemption in section 570.63 of title 29, Code of Federal Regulations.
